references: We maintain this general notion of privacy framework because different notions of privacy can be useful in different situations. For example, the lack of rigor associated with notions such as FL, may make it unsuitable for high security applications, but it may be very useful in protecting users against data breaches on servers, by keeping their data local. One popular choice with rigorous guarantees is DP:

The payment to user iğ‘–i will tend to increase with a lower privacy level, as the platform can better exploit the data, but their sensitivity cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} will increase with ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i}, creating a trade-off.
By specifying tiâ€‹(Ïi;ğ†âˆ’i)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğœŒğ‘–subscriptğ†ğ‘–t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}), the platform effectively creates a game among the users. This situation is depicted in Fig.Â 3.
Each userâ€™s action is the level of privacy that they request for the data they share. Users (players) select their privacy level ÏisubscriptğœŒğ‘–\rho_{i} by considering their utility function uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} and the potential actions of the other players.
The platformâ€™s goal is to design the payments tiâ€‹(Ïi;ğ†âˆ’i)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğœŒğ‘–subscriptğ†ğ‘–t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}) that maximize its net utility Uâ€‹(ğ†)âˆ’ğŸ™Tâ€‹ğ­â€‹(ğ†)ğ‘ˆğ†superscript1ğ‘‡ğ­ğ†U(\bm{\rho})-\mathds{1}^{T}\mathbf{t}(\bm{\rho}). One way to formulate this problem is to consider maximizing this difference at equilibrium points:

NEâ€‹(ğ­)NEğ­\text{NE}(\mathbf{t}) denotes the set of NE strategies induced by the payment function ğ­ğ­\mathbf{t}, which is the vector with payment function tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i} at index iğ‘–i.
Recall that the NE is a stable state such that no user gains by unilaterally changing their strategy. Depending on the circumstances, we may also want to consider equilibrium points in mixed strategies (distributions) over the privacy space. This could make sense if we expect users to continually interact with the platform, making a different choice each time, such that users ultimately converge to their long-run average payoff. In such cases, we can formulate the problem for the platform as:
{maxi}<b >
t(â‹…), P  U(P) - 1^T t(P)
\addConstraint P âˆˆNE(t).


where we have used the shorthand fâ€‹(ğ’«)=ğ”¼ğ†âˆ¼ğ’«â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ†)]ğ‘“ğ’«subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ†ğ’«delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ†f(\mathcal{P})=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\rho}\sim\mathcal{P}}\left[f(\bm{\rho})\right] and ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} represents a distribution over the privacy space â„°â„°\mathcal{E}. Note that in both equationÂ 1 and equationÂ 1 restrictions must be placed on ğ­ğ­\mathbf{t}, otherwise it can be made arbitrarily negative. Individual rationality is a common condition in mechanism design that says that a user can be made no worse off by participation. In Section 5, we consider a fairness constraint.

A notable difference between these axioms and (A.i-iii) is that the efficiency condition is replaced with pseudo-efficiency. Under this condition, the platform may determine the sum of payments awarded to the players, but this sum should in general depend only on the utility itself, and not on how that utility is achieved.

At first glance it may seem that both notions of fairness have exponential computational complexity of Nâ€‹|â„°|Nğ‘superscriptâ„°ğ‘N\left\lvert{\mathcal{E}}\right\rvert^{N}. This is only true for a worst-case exact computation. In order for these notions to be useful in any meaningful way, we must be able to compute them. Thankfully, in practice, Uğ‘ˆU typically has a structure that makes the problem more tractable. In Ghorbani & Zou (2019), Jia etÂ al. (2019), Wang & Jia (2023) and Lundberg & Lee (2017) special structures are used to compute the types of Shapley value sums we are considering with significantly reduced complexity, particularly in cases where the Uğ‘ˆU is related to the accuracy of a deep network. This is critical because we want to compute fair values for large number of users. For example, our platform could be a medical data network with hundreds of hospitals as our users, or a smartphone company with millions of users, and we need to be able to scale computation to accurately compute these fair values.

Fig.Â 2 summarizes our FL formulation. Users can choose from a 333-level privacy space â„°={0,1,2}â„°012\mathcal{E}=\{0,1,2\}. In this case the privacy space is not related to DP, but instead encodes how users choose to share their data with the platform. Let Njsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—N_{j} be the number of users that choose privacy level jğ‘—j. The heterogeneous privacy framework is given in TableÂ 1.

The platformâ€™s goal is to set Î±ğ›¼\alpha such that it maximizes the total amount of utility it receives. Since the NE set depends on Î±ğ›¼\alpha the platform has some control over the behavior of the users. The mechanism design problem in this case reduces to:

Note that this is exactly equationÂ 1, except we have used the fact that Î±â€‹(ğ†)â€‹Uâ€‹(ğ†)=âˆ‘iÏ•iâ€‹(ğ†)ğ›¼ğ†ğ‘ˆğ†subscriptğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ†\alpha(\bm{\rho})U(\bm{\rho})=\sum_{i}\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}). Solving equationÂ 4.2 is a daunting task, due to the complex structure of the constraint, however, it is numerically tractable in this case. The key idea to efficiently solve equationÂ 4.2 is to exploit symmetries in the utility function. For instance, if ğ†â€²superscriptğ†â€²\bm{\rho}^{\prime} is constructed from ğ†ğ†\bm{\rho} by permuting the values Ïi,ÏjsubscriptğœŒğ‘–subscriptğœŒğ‘—\rho_{i},\rho_{j} where ni=njsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—n_{i}=n_{j}, then Uâ€‹(ğ†)=Uâ€‹(ğ†â€²)ğ‘ˆğ†ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ†â€²U(\bm{\rho})=U(\bm{\rho}^{\prime}). This allows us compute Ï•iâ€‹(ğ†)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ†\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) for a much smaller number of representative ğ†ğ†\bm{\rho}, rather than a full combinatorial search. Despite producing the same utility, ğ†ğ†\bm{\rho} and ğ†â€²superscriptğ†â€²\bm{\rho}^{\prime} may have very different stability properties. To deal this this, we can implement an efficient tree search to identify the NEs within each group. Once we have an efficient algorithm for computing NEs, we conduct a grid search to determine the optimal Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Note that for an arbitrary problem, finding the equilibria can be a challenging task, and thus the more difficult it is to compute the equilibria, the more difficult it will be to solve the design problem in equationÂ 1. We provide a full description of our solution in AppendixÂ D.

In the previous section, we considered a complex model, numerically studying the equilibria of the users based on fair payments from the platform, as well as how the platform optimally chooses Î±ğ›¼\alpha.
In this section, we consider a tractable model and theoretically study how the optimal Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*} changes based on the privacy sensitivity of users, under a fairness framework based on Theorem 2.
This section addresses this problem by investigating the incentives of a platform designing a mechanism under the constraint of fairness.

The computational burden in solving equationÂ 5 is in characterizing the constraint, since the objective reduces to a one-dimensional optimization over Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1]. In the previous section, with the knowledge that the game is symmetric, we are able to easily characterize the equilibria as a function of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. If the cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}â€™s are all different, for arbitrary utility functions, the problem essentially reduces to finding the equilibria in a general game. To make this tractable, we will need some assumptions. In Hu & Gong (2020), the specific choice of utility function and payments makes computation of the equilibrium tractable. If we have only two groups of users with different cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} that act together, and a finite privacy space, we can appeal to tools for enumerating equilibria in matrix games (Avis etÂ al., 2010). In this case if the privacy space is also binary, then the equilibria have an analytical solution, which we provide in AppendixÂ E. Like the symmetric case, there are 3 cases for each of the two users as well as corresponding thresholds that depend on c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2} respectively, resulting in 9 total cases. For example, in the case where payment is below the threshold of both users, neither participate at the low-privacy level, when the payment is high enough both participate at the low privacy level, and for the remaining intermediate cases, either only one user chooses the low privacy option, or there is some asymmetric mixed strategy.
